question:
(a) List five factors that affect climate.
(b) Highlight five characteristics of Equatorial climate.
answer:
(a) Factors that affect climate: - latitude; - altitude; - Continentality/distance from the sea, ocean Currents, - planetary winds/pressure belts; - slope and aspect, - industrialization; cloud cover - soil; atural vegetation-insolation.
(b) Characteristics of Equatorial climate: - high temperature all year round-mean monthly temperature of 27°C, small annual range of temperature, - high humidity, relative humidity over 80% - large amount of cloud Over clouds disperse solar insolation, small daily range of temperature of about 5°C, - high annual amount of rainfall greater than 2000mm rain falls throughout the year; more rainfall in Summer; - no marked dry season, double maxima rainfall pattern; rainfall type is usually Convectional; lightning accompanies raintall,-hot and wet always, - zone of trade winds.

question:
(a) Define weathering.
(b) ldentiry three factors that affect weathering.
(c) Describe the processes of exfoliation.
answer:
(a) Definition of weathering: Weathering is the disintegration or decomposition of rocks in situ by physical, chemical or biological processes. (b) Factors that affect weathering: temperature Changes/climate, rainfall/moisture climate, types/nature of rocks; living organisms (plants and animals), - relief/topography; time.
(c) Description or the processes of exfoliation: physIcal mechanical weathering, occurs in desert/arid regions, - plutonic rocks are exposed to the surtace by erosIon, - the removal of the heavy overlying rock materials relax the pressure on the rock; the rocks expand slightly in volume around the exposed surtaces, the expansion makes the exposed side weak and more vulnerable to external forces, expansion causes cracks parallel to the surface, - thin layers on the exposed surface peel off and are called sheeting structures - high temperatures at day causes outer layers of exposed rocks to expand, - drop in temperatures at night causes outer layers of rocks to contract faster than the inner layers.

question:
(a) State two differences between weather and climate.
(b) Name the instruments used in measuring the following weather elements: (i) sunshine (ii) rainfall (iii) cloud cover.
(c) Explain how Wind speed is measured and recorded.
answer:
(a) Differences between weather and climate: weather shows the immediate state of the atmosphere while climate gives the average Condition of the atmosphere, - weather is the condition of the atmosphere as experienced for a short period of time while climate is the condition of the atmosphere as experienced over a long period of time usually for over 35 years, - weather description covers a relatively small area while climate description covers wide areas, - weather descriptions cannot be generalized while climatic descriptions can be generalised, - weather is dominated by one element at a time while climate is dominated by several elements at a time, - weather changes frequently while climate changes after a long period of time, - all weather elements are considered and measured in the description of climate while only selected elements are considered in weather description. (b) Instruments used in measuring weather elements: (i) Sunshine-Sundial/Sunshine Recorder/Campbel strokes recorder/pyranometer (ii) Rainfall- Cloud Cover ceilometers/Oktas/cloud mirror
(c) Explanation of how wind is measured: Measure With anemometer,-anemometer placed open space - anemometer has four metal cups, the cups are fitted to metal arms, - a shaft is connecting the metal arm to a meter  - cups rotate freely on the vertical shaft- the stronger the wind,  the faster the rotation- the number of rotations is indicated on the meter to give the speed of the wind - measured in knot/hour- measured in knot by marine professionals- measured in aeronautical applications; the observation is made twice a day, the measurement is not so reliable because the cups/shaft continue to rotate after the wind stops. Recording of wind speed: recording takes place daily, - usually between the hours of 9 a.m. and 3 p.m., - recording is done in a noted book, day of recording is stated; recording is signed by the observer.

question:
(a)Lst five landforms found in the upper course of a river.
(b) Highlight three differences and two Similarities between an alluvial fan and a delta.
answer:
(a) Land forms found in the upper course of a river:- gorge/canyon; - V-shaped valley Interlocking spur, - cliff; - steep slopes, highland - hanging valley.
(b) Differences between alluvial fan and delta: - alluvial fans are found mostly in arid regions whereas deltas are found both in semi arid and non-arid regions, - deltas are found where rivers enter the sea or lake whereas alluvial fans are found where rivers emerge from a canyon onto lowlands; - alluvial tans are found within continents whereas deltas are found in coastal areas, deltas contain water most of the time whereas alluvial fans are always dry,-alluvial fans are found at the foot of highlands whereas deltas are formed at the mouth of rivers - deltas are relatively flat while alluvial fans are steep in cross profille, - deltas may have swamps, lakes or lagoons while alluvial fans have none of these,- sediments of alluvial fans are usually more Coarse while sediments of deltas are less Coarse, fine silt or clay, deltas have distributaries whereas alluvial fans have dry rill channels, deltas are formed in lower courses of rivers whereas alluvial fans could be formed outsiIde lower Courses of rivers. Similarities between alluvial fan and delta:- both are depositional features -deposits by water action; composed of alluvium, materials sorted according to size and weight, - found on low lands; both are built by heavily laden streams/rivers - both are fan-shaped.

question:

answer:
